TF039000-MADAGASCAR - HEALTH SECTOR
            SUPPORT PROJECT,TF037020-MADAGASCAR - CRESAN
            (MG-PE-1520) AND HEALTH II (MG-PE-51741,TF030210-BELGIUM CTF-NATIONALS,TF030201-FLEMISH CTF-ENVIRONMENT (NATIONAL)

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the outcome of the project is
            satisfactory, and sustainability is likely, with modest
            institutional development impacts. Nonetheless, regardless
            of satisfactory performances, lessons address mainly, the
            borrower's mixed performance during implementation, due
            at the beginning to weak management, jeopardized by the lack
            of political commitment. Though later on, policy dialogue
            between the Government, and the Bank improved, it is
            suggested that a comprehensive policy framework be developed
            by the Government at an early stage, as a basis for donor
            interventions in the sector, with full involvement of
            relevant government officials. A strategy confined uniquely
            to the health sector, may preclude the control of certain
            diseases, i.e., plague, and cholera, which are spread as a
            result of poverty, and unsanitary conditions; thus, a
            complementary multi-sectoral approach would also address
            measures to improve sanitation, and hygiene. Furthermore,
            major reforms, which may be politically sensitive, and
            potentially controversial, such as cost recovery, may better
            be introduced all at once nationwide, rather than
            progressively, provided the necessary preparatory work has
            been achieved. Project design should include implementation
            arrangements by the borrower, to allow flexible
            coordination, and, realistic performance indicators should
            be included in the design, to allow relevant monitoring.
